channel.title: NYT > Science
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: Penguins Become Prey for the Pumas of Patagonia
item.description: In Argentina, the return of pumas brought top predators back to the landscape — much to penguins’ dismay.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil
item.category: Proceedings of the Royal Society B (Journal)

item.title: When the Bones Were Good, These Bees Buried Their Babies
item.description: A cave in the Dominican Republic concealed thousands of years worth of animal bones that had been turned into nests by prehistoric bees.
item.dc:creator: Jack Tamisiea

item.title: How the Pandemic Lockdowns Changed a Songbird’s Beak
item.description: For ecologists, the Covid-19 pandemic has presented a remarkable natural experiment in what can happen to wild animals when humans stay home.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:description: Dark-eyed juncos, normally forest-dwelling, have occupied Los Angeles for about 20 years.

item.title: Turkey’s Largest City Is Threatened by a Lurking Earthquake
item.description: Escalating activity along a fault line in the Sea of Marmara is moving closer to Istanbul, seismologists warn.
item.dc:creator: Robin George Andrews
item.media:description: People gathered in an earthquake assembly area following a 6.2 magnitude temblor in Istanbul in April.

item.title: This Squid Is Playing Peekaboo at the Bottom of the Ocean
item.description: Perhaps it was hiding from predators. Or trying to catch food. Then again, maybe it just wanted to be left alone.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Preston

item.title: A Hot Plant’s Irresistible Signal Makes Beetles Pollinate It
item.description: Ancient plants called cycads say “come hither” in infrared.
item.dc:creator: Sofia Quaglia

item.title: Killer Whales Find an ‘Unlikely Friend’ in Dolphins
item.description: Off the coast of British Columbia, dolphins lead killer whales to salmon and earn their share of lunch, a new study reveals.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil

item.title: Trump Administration Rules Threaten Nobel Prizes Won by Immigrants
item.description: As three immigrants claim Nobel Prizes in science for the United States this year, experts warn that immigration crackdowns could undo American innovation.
item.dc:creator: William J. Broad
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times

item.title: Archaeologists Find Oldest Evidence of Fire-Making
item.description: Neanderthals 400,000 years ago were striking flints to make fires, researchers have found.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer

item.title: Research Flights Over the Atlantic Could Help Improve Atmospheric River Forecasting
item.description: A global effort to better understand moisture-laden rivers in the sky, like those currently battering the West Coast, will take flight in January.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:description: A view out the window of a research mission by NOAA into atmospheric rivers over the Pacific in 2023.

item.title: U.S. Is Seeking Exemption From a European Climate Law, Officials Say
item.description: Diplomats told E.U. officials that the bloc’s law on methane, a potent greenhouse gas, would hurt American oil and gas companies.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: A liquified natural gas tanker. This year the Trump administration signed a deal with the European Union in which Europe pledged to buy American gas in exchange for tariff relief.

item.title: Ruth Kiew Dies at 79; Botanist Made Discoveries in Remote Forests
item.description: Trekking across Malaysia, her adopted country, she found more than 150 unrecorded plant species. “She’s one of the greatest botanists who ever lived,” a colleague said.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter

item.title: Heart Association Revives Theory That Light Drinking May Be Good for You
item.description: The American Heart Association report runs contrary to recent studies — and the group’s own guidelines — that found any amount of alcohol to be harmful.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Colin Clark for The New York Times
item.media:description: While there is no dispute that heavy drinking is harmful to health, the question before experts is whether light to moderate drinking provides more protection from cardiovascular disease than not drinking at all.

item.title: Arctic Report Card Marks Record Temperatures and Rainfall in Arctic
item.description: A yearly checkup on the region documents a warmer, rainier Arctic and 200 Alaskan rivers “rusting” as melting tundra leaches minerals from the soil into waterways.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:description: A tributary of the Kugaaruk River in northern Alaska turning orange from elevated heavy metal concentrations.

item.title: A Powerful New Drug Is Creating a ‘Withdrawal Crisis’ in Philadelphia
item.description: Medetomidine, a veterinary sedative, mixed into fentanyl has sent thousands to hospitals, not only for overdose but for life-threatening withdrawal. It is spreading to other cities.
item.dc:creator: Jan Hoffman and Hannah Yoon
item.media:credit: Hannah Yoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Temple University Hospital emergency entrance.

item.title: F.D.A. Approves Two New Drugs to Treat Gonorrhea
item.description: The sexually transmitted disease has become increasingly resistant to existing antibiotics.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs
item.media:description: Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the bacterium that causes gonorrhea.

item.title: How to Watch the Geminids Meteor Shower Reach Its Peak
item.description: The moon will be about one-third full as one of the year’s last meteor showers becomes most visible.
item.dc:creator: Katrina Miller
item.media:description: A meteor over Lukeville, Ariz., during the Geminids meteor shower in December 2023.

item.title: Review of Medical Cannabis Use Finds Little Evidence of Benefit
item.description: Researchers found a chasm between the health reasons for which the public seeks out cannabis and what gold-standard science actually shows about its effectiveness.
item.dc:creator: Jan Hoffman
item.media:credit: Mohamed Sadek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Addiction experts, who studied hundreds of clinical trials, guidelines and surveys conducted over 15 years, found a gulf between how the public perceives cannabis and what gold-standard science shows.

item.title: Lawsuit Seeks to Stop Oil Exploration in Remote Areas of the Arctic
item.description: A federal lawsuit argues that proposed work by ConocoPhillips could threaten delicate ecosystems in the largest tract of public land in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:description: A ConocoPhillips oil drilling site on the North Slope of Alaska near the Willow site, another ConocoPhillips oil exploration project.

item.title: Trump Panel Abruptly Postpones Release of FEMA Overhaul Recommendations
item.description: The group’s report had been expected to provide a road map for change after months of upheaval at the agency.
item.dc:creator: Scott Dance
item.media:description: Talk of a FEMA overhaul comes as disasters are becoming more frequent and costly as a result of climate change.

item.title: U.S. Helped to Weaken Report at U.N. Environment Talks, Participants Say
item.description: American officials joined Russia, Saudi Arabia and Iran in objecting to language on fossils fuels, biodiversity and plastics in a report that was three years in the making.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:description: The opening session of the 7th United Nations Environment Assembly in Nairobi, Kenya, on Monday.

item.title: Russia Warns Poland Over Arrest of a Researcher Wanted by Ukraine
item.description: Poland detained a Russian archaeologist who works on an ancient site in Crimea, which Russia seized in 2014. Ukraine calls the work illegal.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: The detention center where the Russian archaeologist Alexander Butyagin is held after being detained by Polish authorities, in Warsaw.

item.title: She Studied Mosquitoes to Prevent Malaria. Then She Lost Her Job at U.S.A.I.D.
item.description: Jenny Carlson Donnelly traveled to malaria-affected countries to test mosquitoes and save lives. Then she lost her job at U.S.A.I.D.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.media:credit: Cheriss May for The New York Times

item.title: New Eli Lilly Drug Retatrutide Brought Major Weight Loss in Trial
item.description: The maker of Zepbound reported results from a study of retatrutide, which targets three hormones in the body and led to much more weight loss than any approved drug.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.media:description: Eli Lilly company offices in San Diego. The company reported results of retatrutide, its next-generation weight-loss drug.

item.title: Here’s What to Know About Japan’s Mega Quake Advisory
item.description: Japan’s government says that the chances of a magnitude 8 earthquake have increased. Scientists can’t predict when one will strike, but it represents a meaningful jump over typical odds.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Jiji Press, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A vehicle teetered on a collapsed road in Tohoku Town off the coast of northern Japan.

item.title: How Long Should You Take Antidepressants?
item.description: Clinical guidelines are vague, so we asked psychiatrists what to consider when deciding whether to continue taking these medications.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron

item.title: Gregg Phillips, a Proponent of Election Conspiracy Theories, to Join FEMA
item.description: Gregg Phillips, who spread unsubstantiated claims of mass voter fraud in the 2016 election, will join the agency’s leadership, the Trump administration confirmed.
item.dc:creator: Scott Dance
item.media:description: Gregg Phillips, right, onstage in 2022 with Catherine Engelbrecht, with whom he has led True the Vote, a conservative nonprofit group.

item.title: A Surrogacy Firm Told Parents-to-Be Their Money Was Safe. Suddenly, It Vanished.
item.description: Surro Connections held itself out as a reliable business. Now, clients have lost as much as tens of thousands of dollars meant to compensate women carrying their pregnancies.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Kliff
item.media:credit: Jackie Molloy for The New York Times

item.title: Our Children’s Trust Suit Asks Montana Court to Block Some New Laws
item.description: The young plaintiffs, who won a major case over climate change policy in 2023, argue that legislators are illegally ignoring the effects of fossil fuels.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Janie Osborne for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rikki Held, the named plaintiff in Held v. Montana, in June 2023. The same plaintiffs are asking the state’s top court to prevent legislators from undermining their victory.
